block.p: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.
Opera

''DON PASQUALE.'' For more than 30 years, the independent, community-based Bronx Opera Company has been presenting standard repertory operatic works (and occasionally unusual fare like Nielsen's ''Maskarade'') as well as giving performance opportunities to young singers and introducing audiences to opera. The company's current offering is Donizetti's popular ''Don Pasquale,'' performed in English. Michael Spierman will conduct and Nathaniel Merchant directs. Lovinger Theater at Lehman College, 250 Bedford Park Boulevard West, the Bronx; today and tomorrow at 8 p.m. Tickets are $25, $20 and $15; $23, $18 and $13 for students and the elderly. Reservations: (212) 201-1490 (Anthony Tommasini).

Reservations: (212) 201-1490 (Anthony Tommasini).

LA GRAN SCENA OPERA. This all-male troupe has raised the skewering of the opera world's pretensions to the level of high, or at least tipsy, art. As usual, the company's founder and artistic director, Ira Siff, takes center stage as Madame Vera Galupe-Borszkh, this time in ''Murder Most Melodious.'' If you haven't seen the company before, be prepared for an evening of outrageous hilarity; if you have, be prepared for perhaps a touch too much repetitiousness and predictability. Tomorrow at 8 p.m. and Sunday at 7 p.m., Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-4100. Tickets: $25 to $100 (James R. Oestreich).
Classical

ABSOLUTE ENSEMBLE. Kristjan Jarvi conducts his group in a program of Erkki-Sven Tuur's ensemble pieces under the collective title ''Architectonics.'' Mr. Tuur's music has something of the calm and simplicity associated with his fellow-countryman Arvo Part, but he has been influenced too by the glistening rush of American minimalism. Today at 8 p.m., discussion at 7 p.m., Miller Theater, Broadway at 116th Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 854-7799. Tickets: $15 (Paul Griffiths).

BACHMANN-KLIBONOFF-FRIDMAN. This fine young piano trio has been offering a series of thematic programs that explore a great expanse of the repertory, organized primarily by national styles. The closing program steps away from musical nationalism and looks at the tango, the Argentine dance that flourished during the 20th century as the waltz did in the 19th. Included are works by Albeniz, Ravel and Piazzolla. Tonight at 7 (with a preconcert talk at 6:30), Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, Manhattan, (212) 685-0008, extension 347. Tickets: $30, $20 for library members (Allan Kozinn).

BARGEMUSIC. There are few better places in the city to hear chamber music than on this barge floating on the East River, with its live, intimate acoustics and its spectacular view of lower Manhattan. Good weather will only enhance the experience, and the performances are often as fine as the setting. Tonight, the McDermott sisters (Kerry, violinist; Maureen, cellist; and Anne-Marie, pianist) join the violist Paul Neubauer in a varied program, ranging from Mendelssohn to Piazzolla. And tomorrow and on Sunday, Joseph Silverstein, violinist; Fred Sherry, cellist; and William Wolfram, pianist, play works of Beethoven, Clara Schumann and Brahms. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, and Sunday at 4 p.m., Bargemusic, Fulton Ferry Landing under the Brooklyn Bridge, Brooklyn, (718) 624-4061. Tickets: $23; $20 for the elderly; $15 for students (Oestreich).

BOLCOM AND MORRIS. The composer and pianist William Bolcom and the mezzo-soprano Joan Morris, who are married to each other, have long made a specialty of American popular song. In a program called ''A Very Dry Martini,'' they offer works by Rodgers and Hart, Rodgers and Hammerstein, Cole Porter, Kurt Weill, Eubie Blake and Lerner and Lowe. Tonight at 8, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street. Tickets, $30. The concert is sold out, but returns may be available beginning at 7; standing room tickets, at $15, may be available at the door; (212) 570-3949 (Kozinn).

THE DESSOFF CHOIRS. The Dessoff Choirs, 75 years old this season and now directed by Kent Trittle, celebrates with a program including Gian Carlo Menotti's ''madrigal fable'' called ''The Unicorn, the Gorgon and the Manticore'' together with Marshall Coid's new ''Whitman Cantata (Of Love, Death, Nature and the Soul).'' Terrance Barber is the countertenor for Mr. Coid's piece. Tomorrow night at 8 at Alice Tully Hall. Tickets are $25, $20 for students and the elderly; (212) 721-6500 (Bernard Holland).

ENSEMBLE FOR EARLY MUSIC. This enterprising ensemble of period instrument players and singers is offering Laudate Matrem -- ''In Praise of Motherhood'' -- a program in honor of Mother's Day. Included are selections from the Cantigas de Santa Maria, motets by Thomas Morely and Francisco Guerrero, as well as Italian laude and canzonets. The group's performers include Mark Rimple, Wayne Hankin, Todd Frizzell, Dan Rigazzi, Mark Sullivan and Jon Szabo. Tonight at 8 and tomorrow at 3, Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, (212) 280-0330. Tickets: $35 and $60 (Kozinn).

VLADIMIR FELTSMAN. The enormous amount of publicity that the pianist Vladimir Feltsman attracted as an emigre from the Soviet Union in the 1980's made him a celebrity. In the long run it did not help his reputation as a pianist, though, for when the reality of his work failed to match the enormous build-up, critics were unusually blunt in their assessments. He has been working solidly over the years as a conductor and teacher as well as a pianist, and winning many admirers. His program this weekend at the 92nd Street Y should reveal much about the current state of his artistry. The program includes works by Haydn and Chopin and Brahms's demanding ''Handel Variations.'' 92nd Street Y (corner of Lexington Avenue and East 92nd Street), Tomorrow at 8 p.m. Tickets: $30; $15 for students and the elderly one hour before the show; (212) 996-1100 (Tommasini).

MATTHIAS GOERNE. Here, from a young German singer, is one of the loveliest baritone voices you will ever hear, but the precise uses to which it is put are not always as easy to certify. In Schubert's ''Winterreise'' a year ago at Carnegie Hall, Mr. Goerne proved intrusively finicky, manipulating every splendid syllable, tone and color. Here, with greater naturalness, one hopes, in a hall perhaps better suited to the size of his voice and to the repertory, he presents more songs by Schubert, interspersed with a like amount by Hanns Eisler. Eric Schneider is the pianist. Sunday at 2 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, (212) 721-6500. Tickets: $38 (Oestreich).

DINA KUZNETSOVA. The Marilyn Horne Foundation does important work supporting young vocal artists in their desire to give song recitals. The foundation has a good track record in uncovering promising singers. On Sunday afternoon at the Kosciuszko Foundation, Dina Kuznetsova, a Moscow-born soprano who sang the title role in Handel's ''Rodelinda'' in a production last summer by the Music Academy of the West in Santa Barbara, Calif., will present a recital program with the pianist Thomas Bagwell. Her program includes works by Rossini, Wolf, Barber, Szymanowsky, Rachmaninoff and Tchaikovsky. The Kosciuszko Foundation, 15 East 65th Street. Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $15; the performance is sold out but returns may be available; (212) 734-2130 (Tommasini).

MANHATTAN VIRTUOSI. This program, offered as a tribute to the Ukrainian conductor Natan Rakhlin, who died in 1979, complements the familiar, by Berlioz, Tchaikovsky and Saint-Saens, with the truly unusual. Here, in arrangements by the orchestra's conductor, Arkady Leytush, are a symphony by Mussorgsky, reconstructed and orchestrated from two piano sketches; Bach's C minor Organ Prelude (BWV 546); and Hampson Sisler's ''Cosmic Divide.'' Sunday at 3 p.m., Great Hall, Cooper Union, Third Avenue at Seventh Street, (212) 866-2958. Tickets: $15; $10 for students and the elderly (Oestreich).

NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC. Sir Colin Davis has always been an elegant Mozartean, and Alfred Brendel's Mozart usually captures both the depth and playfulness in the music. They are collaborating on the Piano Concerto No. 22 in an all-Mozart program that also includes the Symphonies Nos. 28 and 38. Tonight and tomorrow at 8. Avery Fisher Hall (212) 721-6500. Tickets: $26 to $92; the performances are sold out, but returns may be available (Kozinn).

ORION STRING QUARTET. In six programs sponsored by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center under the title Beethoven 2000, this talented group presents its first complete survey of the Beethoven quartets. The series is meant to honor charitable organizations that in various ways make music available to children, with a different organization recognized at each concert. The Orion players offer Beethoven's Opuses 18, No. 3; 59, No. 1; and 135 tonight and Opuses 18, No. 1; 59, No. 2; and 133 on Sunday. Tonight and Sunday at 8 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, (212) 875-5788. Admission is free, but tickets are required. All tickets have been distributed, but any returned tickets will be available five minutes before the performances. (Oestreich).

ORPHEUS CHAMBER ENSEMBLE. Yaddo, the bucolic community for visual artists, writers and composers in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., was founded 100 ago. To celebrate, a festival of concerts, readings, exhibits and films is being presented in New York and in the region of the community for the next three months. The third of three programs presented by the esteemed Orpheus Chamber ensemble at the Society for Ethical Culture offers works written by composers who have resided at Yaddo. Several of these were actually written there. Tomorrow's program at the Society for Ethical Culture includes works by Bernstein, Ned Rorem, Sebastian Currier, Barbara Kolb, Michael Torke and a premiere by Steven Burke. Society for Ethical Culture, Central Park West at 64th Street. Tomorrow at 8 p.m. Tickets: $15. Information: (212) 592-4156 (Tommasini).

SAINT FRANCOIS D'ASSISE. Musical glory. Three scenes from Messiaen's magnificent opera are being presented by a splendid cast led by David Wilson-Johnson as St. Francis and Heidi Grant Murphy as the Angel, with the wonderful Robert Spano conducting the Brooklyn Philharmonic and the Westchester Oratorio Society: nearly 300 people will be onstage producing a feast of brilliant orchestral colors, bird songs, magical chant melodies and the music of heaven. A rare opportunity, not to be missed. Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100. Tickets: $8 to $40 (Griffiths).

DAWN UPSHAW. This thoughtful soprano seems to like presenting expansive series rather than single recitals. In the first installment of her three-part ''Images of Dawn,'' she looked at French music. The second installment, tomorrow, is a collaboration with the Kronos Quartet that looks at contemporary works with links to traditional and folk styles. Among the composers whose works are included are Osvaldo Golijov, Rahul Dev Burman, Aleksandra Vrebalov, Anibal Troilo, Enrique Rangel, Gabriela Ortiz and Al-Shayk Abul-ila Muhammad. Tomorrow at 8 p.m., the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue, at 84th Street, (212) 721-6500. Tickets: $38. (Kozinn).

VOICES OF ASCENSION. Dennis Keene and this noted chorus of professionals have already contributed strongly to the commemorations of the 250th anniversary of Bach's death this year with an excellent performance of the B minor Mass at Alice Tully Hall. Here is another Bach program, this one combining four of the motets with solo vocal, chamber and organ works. Expect only the best from these performers. Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue at 10th Street, (212) 358-1469. Tickets: $10 to $35 (Oestreich).
Dance

ALVIN AILEY AMERICAN DANCE THEATER. The eloquent Ailey dancers in performances of a repertory of 15 dances, seen in whole or in excerpt. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $15 to $64. New Jersey Performing Arts Center, One Center Street, Newark; (888) 466-5722 (Jennifer Dunning).

AMERICAN BALLET THEATER. Stage-filling opulence and a scampish sense of humor are combined in ''Don Quixote,'' which will be performed by American Ballet Theater in its first weekend back at the Met. Tonight's cast will be headed by Paloma Herrera as the irrepressible Kitri and Jose Manuel Carreno as Basil the barber, her dashing lover. Julie Kent and Angel Corella take over tomorrow afternoon, followed in the evening by Susan Jaffe and Julio Bocca. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m. Tickets: $20 to $75. . Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center; (212) 362-6000 (Dunning).

ARIANE ANTHONY AND COMPANY. Ariane Anthony, a sparklingly true original, cites the writers Wallace Stevens and Samuel Beckett as the inspirations for her new ''Why Imagine Golden Birds?,'' drawn from Stevens's ''Thirteen Ways of Looking at a Blackbird,'' and ''Seeing I,'' a male trio drawn from Beckett's final prose poem, ''Stirrings Still.'' Tomorrow, Monday and Tuesday at 8 p.m.; Sunday at 6 p.m. Tickets: $12; $10 for students and the elderly; TDF vouchers accepted. Construction Company, 10 East 18th Street, Manhattan, (212) 924-7882 (Dunning).

BEPPIE BLANKERT. This Dutch choreographer's ''Double Track'' pairs dancers with mirrors, and the effect is spectacular. Thanks to illusions involving reflections, people seem to vanish and reappear magically while they wait for a train. Tonight and tomorrow at 7 and 9; Sunday at 7 p.m., Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-0077. Tickets: $15 (Jack Anderson).

TRISHA BROWN DANCE COMPANY. A benefit performance on Sunday night features Mikhail Baryshnikov as guest artist in Trisha Brown's ''Homemade.'' Among the other weekend highlights is ''Rapture to Leon James,'' a new work to jazz music. Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 2 and benefit at 7:30 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800. Tickets: $35; benefit ticket prices and availability: (212) 582-0040 (Anderson).

SEAN CURRAN COMPANY. Sean Curran offers choreographic meditations on love, longing and loss. His ''Approaching a City'' examines the differences between loneliness and solitude. ''Seven Laments'' suggests how loss can simultaneously break hearts and startle people awake. ''That Place, Those People,'' concerns the ways in which memories influence our present relationships. Tonight, tomorrow night and Sunday night at 8:30, St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, East Village. Tickets: $15; (212) 674-8194 (Anderson).

COSTAS: ''THEME AND VARIATIONS.'' Images from ballet, lyrical and full of passion, will be on view in an exhibit by the dance photographer known as Costas. The exhibit also includes dance sculptures by Andrew De Vries, paintings by Douglas Hofmann and aquatints by Roy Fairchild-Woodard. Today and tomorrow (and Monday through Saturday through July 1) from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Free. The Gallery at Lincoln Center, Concourse Level just beneath the Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center; (212) 580-4673 (Dunning).

''DONG DONG TOUCHING THE MOONS'' The avant-garde choreographer and performer Sin Cha Hong makes a rare return to the New York stage in this multi-national workshop production, held in connection with a recently ended new-technology conference at the Kitchen. The music is by Jin Hi Kim. Ms. Hong will perform with Parul Shah, an Indian kathak dancer. Tonight and tomorrow at 8 p.m. Tickets: $15. The Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-5793 (Dunning).

MAURA NGUYEN DONOHUE. ''Righteous Babes'' examines political violence, domestic violence, race relations, cross-dressing and gender roles in choreography that draws upon gymnastics, martial arts, contact improvisation and various American and Asian theater styles. Tonight, tomorrow and Sunday at 8:30 p.m., Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, East Village, (212) 477-5288. Tickets: $15 (Anderson).

TERRY HOLLIS. This workshop production of Terry Hollis's theater and dance piece ''NewSex'' is set to music by Sean Meehan. Sunday at 3 p.m.; Thursday at 8 p.m. and May 21 at 3 p.m. Tickets: $12; $8 for students and the elderly; TDF vouchers accepted. Dixon Place at Vineyard 26, 309 East 26th Street, Manhattan, (212) 532-1546 (Dunning).

''JOYCE SOHO PRESENTS.'' Dance by Claire Porter, Trisha Bauman, Nathalie Paoli and Victor Quijada will be performed in this second of three festival weekends. Tonight and tomorrow (and May 18-20) at 8 p.m. Tickets: $10; TDF vouchers accepted. Joyce SoHo, 155 Mercer Street, (212) 334-7479 (Dunning)
JUILLIARD SCHOOL DANCE DIVISION: ''YOUNG CHOREOGRAPHERS' EVENING.'' Say you saw them when. Tomorrow at 8 p.m. Free. Juilliard Theater, 155 West 65th Street, Manhattan, (212) 769-7406 (Dunning).

MOVING ON. The closing weekend of this festival will feature work by eight choreographers, including Isabel Gotzkowsky, Mark Haim, Nicholas Leichter and Lonne Moretton, to raise money for the Dance Space Center and its classes. Tomorrow at 8 p.m.; Sunday at 5 and 8 p.m. Tickets: $20. Evolving Arts Theater, Dance Space Center, 451 Broadway near Grand Street, one block north of Canal Street; (212) 625-8369 (Dunning).

LEE NAGRIN. Lee Nagrin's new performance-art piece, ''The Valley of Iao,'' takes the viewer along with her on a mystical remembered journey through the dying of a loved one in Hawaii. Tonight and tomorrow at 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3:30 and 8 p.m. Tickets: $20 (Fridays and Saturdays); $15 (Sundays); TDF vouchers accepted. La MaMa E.T.C., 74A East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 475-7710 (Dunning).

KAMAL SINCLAIR: ''THE BEAT.'' Kamal Sinclair explores the power of music as a force for social unity and spiritual transcendence, with help from the performance artist Robbie McCauley, the poet Mustafa Shakir and the tap dancer Baakari Wilder. Tonight and tomorrow (and Thursdays through Saturdays through May 20) at 8 p.m. Tickets: $25; $15 for students. Context Studios, 28 Avenue A, at Second Street, East Village, (212) 802-9350 (Dunning).

TURKISH FOLK DANCE AND MUSIC. Traditional Turkish folk music and dance directed by Tayyar Akdeniz and presented by the World Music Institute. Tonight at 8. Tickets: $19 and $23. Fashion Institute of Technology, 227 West 27th Street, Chelsea, (212) 545-7536 (Dunning).

Correction: May 13, 2000, Saturday A music listing in Weekend yesterday misidentified the hall where the Bronx Opera Company is presenting Donizetti's ''Don Pasquale'' this weekend. The performance at 8 tonight is at the John Jay College Theater, 899 10th Avenue, at 59th Street, in Manhattan, not at Lehman College in the Bronx.
